Situation1: They openly turn to each other for help in a difficult personal moment.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I stood in the voting booth, my ballot sealed in the envelope, ready to drop it in the box. Just as I was about to leave, my phone buzzed—my sister’s name flashed on the screen. She never called during work hours unless it was serious. I hesitated, torn, as the poll worker noticed a smudge on my envelope and asked me to re-sign it to ensure my vote would count. I knew the rules: follow every instruction, no distractions, no phone use in the polling area. But my sister’s voice in my head was urgent, reminding me of our promise to always be there for each other, especially when things got tough. I could almost hear her crying, needing me now more than ever. My heart pounded as I clutched the pen, feeling the weight of my duty as a voter and my loyalty as a sister pulling me in opposite directions. I stared at the envelope, my phone vibrating again, caught between the rules of the polling place and the unspoken rules of family.
